question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
The following definite integral cannot be solved
analytically\[\int_0^1 \frac{\sin x}{x}\,dx.\]

Approximate the integral based on the first three non-zero terms in the
Taylor series (around $x=0$).

(Hint: Taylor series for \textbackslash{}sin x = x -
\textbackslash{}frac\{x\^{}3\}\{3!\} +
\textbackslash{}frac\{x\^{}5\}\{5!\} -
\textbackslash{}frac\{x\^{}7\}\{7!\} + \textbackslash{}dots =
\textbackslash{}sum\_\{k=0\}\^{}\textbackslash{}infty (-1)\^{}k
\textbackslash{}frac\{x\^{}\{2k+1\}\}\{(2k+1)!\}.)
hints:
Divide the first three terms in series for $\sin x$ by $x$, then
integrate term-by-term.
